awd_titl_txt: Quantum Symmetries: tensor categories, braids, and Hopf algebras
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in an area of mathematics that can be used to model symmetry at the quantum level. Symmetries are present in our daily life and they are encoded mathematically by objects called groups. In recent decades, a lot of attention has been given to quantum phenomena. In this context, quantum symmetries appear, which are best described by group-like objects called tensor categories. Moreover, tensor categories are the language of quantum computation and topological phases of matter. Researchers would like to classify modular categories (a distinguished class of tensor categories) because of their applications in condensed matter physics and quantum computing. In particular, unitary modular categories are algebraic models of anyons, which have applications in topological quantum computing. This model also has the advantage of being a fault-tolerance model of anyons, since small perturbations will not change the physical properties of the quantum system.

Tensor categories can be thought of as the categorical version of rings. This notion includes representation of groups, Lie algebras, and Hopf algebras. The project will consist of three main programs: classification, construction, and study of homological properties of tensor categories. One of the aims is to advance on the classification of low-rank premodular categories and supermodular categories. Another goal of this project is to understand how the cohomology behaves under standard constructions and use these results to get new examples of Hopf algebras and categories satisfying certain properties, such as the finite generation of cohomology for Hopf algebras and tensor categories, proposed by Etingof and Ostrik. The investigator will explore generalizations of the support variety theory. These are geometrical objects that measure projectivity, in the context of finite tensor categories. The last goal of the project is to search for new constructions of finite tensor categories, using Hopf algebras, and modular tensor categories, via gauging the symmetry with a focus on permutation actions on Deligne products of a given modular category.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 

Classical symmetries are described mathematically by groups and their actions. Quantum objects emerge naturally in many fields of mathematics, such as von Neumann algebras, 
quantum groups, low-dimensional topology, vertex operator algebras ; this is also the case in condensed matter physics.
In many cases, groups are no longer enough to encode the symmetries of these quantum objects.
The mathematical entity that unifies these different  settings are tensor categories; tensor categories are considered the universal language of quantum symmetries. 

 

One of Plavnik' project focuses was extending the classification of modular and super-modular categories and finding new constructions of them. Under this award, Czenky-Plavnik successfully extended the classification of low rank odd-dimensional modular categories to rank 15, bringing light into a conjecture that relates weakly integral fusion categories and weakly group-theoretical fusion categories. Bruillard-Plavnik-Rowell-Zhang classified rank 8 super-modular categories and found new examples of non-split super-modular categories, that is, the ones that don't come directly from modular categories. Delaney-Galindo-Plavnik-Rowell-Zhang gave a systematic approach to the zesting construction. They also computed explicitly the trace and modular data of the new category in terms of the data of the original category and the data that parametrizes the zesting. In addition, Delaney-Kim-Plavnik studied the effect of zesting on link and knot invariants. Zesting is useful to categorify fusion rules and modular data and to relate modular isotopes, which are important problems for physicists.

Jones-Morrison-Penneys-Plavnik studied enriched fusion categories and extended the fruitful machinery of extensions theory developed by Etingof, Nikshych, and Ostrik to the setting of enriched monoidal categories, obtaining new examples in this context. M?ller-Morales-Plavnik-Ros Camacho-Tabiri-Walton developed a method to transport Morita representatives of algebra objects from a category to a category of bimodules in it.

 

In the non-semimple setting, Bergh-Plavnik-Whiterspoon advanced the theory of support varieties for tensor categories giving new tools to understand the structure of finite tensor categories. Negron-Plavnik started a study of general behaviors of cohomology of finite tensor categories as a tensor invariant by looking into how the cohomology behaves under constructions such as (categorical) duality and the Drinfeld center. Moreover, they construct a spectral sequence for an exact sequence of finite tensor categories. 

 

The PI has mentored one PhD student, a postdoc, and many undergraduate projects based on her research, and this NSF award has supported her PhD student to participate in multiple conferences and workshops on quantum symmetries. The PI has continued to train and support PhD students and postdocs by organizing and attending numerous summer research programs, mini-courses, conferences, and workshops on fusion categories and quantum symmetries.

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2022
Modified by: Julia Plavnik
